intro: Agalinis pseudaphylla, commonly known as the narrowleaf false foxglove, is a herbaceous perennial native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, which includes many parasitic and semi-parasitic plants. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. Its flowers are tubular and usually pink or purple, arranged in spikes. It is characterized by its narrow leaves and lack of true roots, relying on mycorrhizal associations for nutrient uptake.
